The  Investment  Program  will  improve  water  supply  and  sanitation 
(WSS)  services  in  provincial  cities  and  secondary  towns  across 
eight  provinces.  Physical  investments  include  rehabilitation  and

customer  awareness  campaign  and  hygiene  promotion,  results

included in a Design and Monitoring Framework. 
 
The multitranche financing facility (MFF) offers more flexibility to the 
Government  than  other  lending  modalities  currently  available  from 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB). It creates a sound platform for 
a long term partnership in the sector, and combines project finance 
with  management  and  institutional  support.  Because  it  front-loads 
key  analytical  work  at  the  start,  the  modality  allows  ADB  and 
Government  teams  to  place  greater  emphasis  on  implementation. 
Financing  will  be  matched  closely  to  project  readiness.  Tranches 
will  be  prepared  (including  design  work)  with  funding  provided 
under  previous  ones.  This  should  speed  up  contract  awards, 
disbursements  and  results.  A  stand-alone  project  modality  would 
not  offer  the  same  predictability  and  continuity,  a  program  loan 
would  not  address  investment  needs  and  a  sector  loan  is  more 
suitable for smaller scale and repetitive or similar investments. The 
underlying policies for the Investment Program are embedded in a 
policy framework approved by the Government.

an  amount  of  $709  million  between  2008–2012.  The  policy 
framework calls for greater institutional effectiveness, better service 
performance  and  management, 
improved  operational  and

Finally,  the  policy  framework  adds  water  quality  and  continuity  to 
the  service  targets.  The  strategy  on  poverty  reduction  and  welfare

Tranche  1  of  the  Investment  Program  will  follow  a  sector  loan 
approach.  All  other  tranches  will  be  fully  prepared  and  designed 
before approving their financing. Most first tranche investments are 
ready for implementation but a few require further preparatory work. 
The  sector  loan  approach  allows  the  authorities  to  get  the 
Investment Program off the ground within this financial year and in 
this  manner  ensure  momentum  for  management  changes  in  the 
sector. 
 
The  desired  impact  of  the  Investment  Program  is  better  public 
health  and hygiene  in  the  eight  target  provinces.  The  outcome  will 
be  increased  access  to  safer  and  more  reliable  water  supply  and 
sanitation services for 3 million residents. 
 
The  proposed  Investment  Program  is  estimated  at  $375  million, 
accounting for 31.3% of the sector's investment needs up to 2012.

I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
Of  Uzbekistan’s  26.9  million  people  (January  2009),  9.6  million  (36%)  live  in  urban 
centers and 17.2 million (64%) in rural areas. The average population density is 60 inhabitants 
per  square  kilometer  (km2),  one  of  the  highest  in  Central  Asia.  The  population  density  ranges 
from more than 565 inhabitants per km2 in Andijan Province to only 9 inhabitants per km2 in the 
Karakalpakstan region. The annual population growth is 1.4%.1 
 
The  water  supply  and  sanitation  (WSS)  systems  were  established  under  the  former 
3. 
Soviet  Union.  These  were  all  owned  and  operated  by  public  enterprises,  supervised  by 
government  ministries  and  funded  from  the  central  budget.  Most  of  the  vodokanals  (water 
supply  and  sanitation  agencies)  have  yet  to  adopt  modern  management  and  commercial 
practices. Many are short on accountability and lack incentives to improve services. Inasmuch 
as water production facilities and customer connections are unmetered, consumption and tariffs 
follow  nominal  rates.  As  a  result,  the  vodokanals  are  poorly  managed  and  underfunded;  the 
water  and  wastewater  services  are  unreliable.  Further,  most  WSS  systems  have  reached  the 
end of their economic lives and now require extensive rehabilitation. 
 
4. 

Water supply. The water supply service across most provinces is poor: 
(i) 

Urban  coverage.  In  urban  areas  it  is  fairly  high  at  89%,  but  its  reliability, 
continuity, or the duration of supplies are low. Rural coverage is low. 
Continuity.  Supplies  are  intermittent—sometimes  less  than  2  hours/day—with 
low flow and pressure.  
Quality. High variability is observed across the country. Many rural areas do not 
have access to potable water. Treated water is rationed for many consumers. For

Investment  Program  based  on  five  grounds.  First,  the  modality  provides  flexibility  to  the 
Government  and  ADB:  It  allows  both  parties  to  readily  modify  the  amount  and  timing  of  ADB 
contributions under each tranche. This is important in case the Government can raise additional 
financing  from  other  sources  (such  as  the  private  sector)  or  it  needs  more  time  to  finalize  the 
financing  packages  (design,  documentation,  reforms,  and  counterpart  financing).  Another 
element behind this flexibility is that the financing to be provided by ADB can be closely linked to 
the availability of resources within ADB (a matter made clear to the Government), as well as to 
compliance  with  warranties  and  representations  made  under  the  framework  financing 
agreement (FFA). 
 
33. 
Second,  financing  under  the  MFF  can  be  linked  to  technical,  institutional,  safeguards, 
and other project readiness filters. The authorities can make specific loan conversions under the 
facility  when  projects  are  ready  for  execution.  This  approach  facilitates  advance  actions, 
including documentation preparation and establishment of relevant administrative arrangements. 
The  MFF  also  combines  the  physical  investments  with  advisory  services.  The  latter  include 
financing to advance work on capacity and policy actions, which at times could be precursors to 
making  the  actual  physical  investments.  Third,  the  MFF  allows  ADB,  the  Government,  and  its 
partners to link the financing more closely to changes in the cost of projects bundled under each 
tranche. This avoids problems associated with cost overruns. Fourth, the modality allows ADB 
to enter into a medium-term partnership with the Government and its cofinancing partners, and 
in the process to create stability and credibility for the financing plan.  
 
34. 
Fifth, all the conditions for the use of an MFF are in place: there is a strategic context, 
road map, policy framework, investment program, and financing plan. The channeling of funding 
via an MFF provides ADB, the Government, and cofinanciers with a chance to avoid repetitive 
processing  tasks.  The  modality  moves  analytical  work  up  front,  leaving  resources  and  multi-
entry points for ADB and its partners to focus on execution, capacity, and reforms.

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACT, AND RISKS 

A. 

General Gains 

73. 
The Investment Program will benefit approximately 3 million residents by 2018 through 
safer,  more  reliable  and  affordable  piped  water  supplies;  improved  wastewater  management 
and sanitation; and good hygiene behavior. Water supply duration will improve from the current 
2–8  hours  per  day  to  more  than  20  hours  per  day.  Coverage  will  increase  to  more  than  95% 
with meter connections and physical losses will reduce to less than 30%. Sewerage coverage 
will increase to 70% in the targeted provincial capitals. The beneficiaries represent about 11% of 
the country’s total population and more than 31% of its urban residents. Rural residents in peri-
urban  areas  of  subproject  towns  will  also  benefit.  Health  benefits,  and  particularly  for  women, 
from the physical investments in safe water supply and improved wastewater management will 
be maximized as people become more knowledgeable and aware of health and hygiene issues 
and they are able to avoid the drudgery of collecting water. Participating provinces will benefit 
economically from increased productivity as public health improves, less time is spent collecting 
water,  and  water  supply  services  are  more  reliable.  Town  residents  will  also  benefit  from  cost 
savings in health care. 
 
B. 

Poverty Reduction 

The Investment Program will bring about improvements to health, living conditions, and 
74. 
productivity  of  local  residents  while  contributing  to  poverty  reduction  in  the  target  areas.  Of 
about  3  million  total  beneficiaries,  approximately  25%  of  households  are  classified  as  poor. 
Many  of  these  do  not  have  piped  drinking  water  and  make  use  of  street  standpipes,  where 
water is provided daily according to set schedules but with frequent interruptions. Benefits from 
an improved water supply system will accrue to all present users, and poor households will be 
fully  integrated  into  the  improved  system.  Improving  the  wastewater  management  system  will 
benefit  the  population  residing  in  downstream  areas,  including  the  rural  population.  Improved 
access  to  safe  and  reliable  drinking  water  and  wastewater  management  will  improve  hygiene 
and  sanitation  practices,  reduce  the  incidence  of  waterborne  diseases,  and  improve  general 
public health. This will reduce household costs for medical care and the number of sick days for 
adults  and  children.  Poverty  and  social  analysis  will  be  conducted  while  preparing  each

Gender Impact 

75. 
The  Investment  Program  will  directly  reduce  the  workload  of  women  and  girls  who  are 
traditionally  responsible  for  collecting  and  storing  water  for  the  household.  It  will  free  up  their 
time  and  provide  them  opportunity  to  become  more  involved  in  social,  economic  and 
educational  activities.  Female-headed  households  living  in  apartments  in  urban  areas  will 
particularly  benefit  from  improvements,  because  they  currently  have  few  alternatives  to  the 
intermittent  and  inadequate  water  supply.  Data  from  recent  surveys  suggest  that  because  of 
household  water  shortages  women  and  girls  bathe  less  compared  with  men  and  boys.  Males 
are able to bathe publicly in rivers and canals, but this is not an option for females. Similarly, the 
shortage of water means houses are not cleaned as often as necessary, thus contributing to the 
incidence of illnesses related to unsanitary and poor physical conditions. The gender action plan 
is in Appendix 14.

Environmental Impacts and Benefit 

79. 
The  Investment  Program  is  designed  to  maximize  environmental  and  public  health 
benefits. Its physical components include rehabilitation and limited expansion of water sources, 
water  distribution  networks,  and  wastewater  management  and  sanitation  systems.  Initial 
environmental examinations (IEEs) show that net environmental benefits are positive and large. 
These include more and better quality drinking water from the water supply subprojects; better 
public  health,  particularly  fewer  waterborne  diseases  through  water  supply,  sewerage,  and 
wastewater  management  investments;  and  improved  aesthetics  as  a  result  of  better  water 
supply, sewerage, and wastewater management. 
 
80. 
The environmental subproject selection criteria will ensure that the subprojects under the 
Investment Program will have no significant negative environmental impacts and no impact on 
environmentally  sensitive  areas.  Any  subproject  with  significant  adverse  environmental  impact 
will  be  ineligible.  The  subprojects  will  use  simple,  appropriate,  and  low-cost  technology.  Any 
potential negative environmental impact is mostly localized and temporary, and it can largely be 
avoided  through  proper  subproject  design,  good  construction  practices,  and  other  tested 
mitigation  measures.  In  addition,  contract-level  environmental  management  plans  will  be 
incorporated in bidding and contract documents. Contractors will be supervised and subprojects' 
environmental  performance  monitored  and  reported  in  accordance  with  the  environmental 
assessment  and  review  framework  (EARF).  All  sample  Tranche  1  subprojects  are  category  B 
subprojects according to ADB’s Environment Policy (2002). The summary initial environmental

Appendixes K and L. The EARF, which will ensure the remaining subprojects’ compliance with 
the environmental requirements of the Government and ADB, is in Supplementary Appendix J.

the  purposes  of  Tranche  1  investments.  The  same  approach  will  be  followed  for  all  the  other 
tranches.  The  resident  mission  and  the  headquarters  teams  will  work  closely  and  seamlessly 
with each other on implementation. The capability of vodokanals in meeting the operation and 
maintenance of the expanded WSS systems is a priority under the Investment Program. Long

compliance  with  ADB  safeguards,  the  Program  includes  environmental  and  resettlement 
frameworks and plans and a social and environmental subunit has been established in PPMU.

URBAN WATER AND SANITATION SECTOR ANALYSIS 

The  Government  of  Uzbekistan  puts  high  priority  on  improving  water  supply  and 
1. 
sanitation  (WSS)  services.  It  recognizes  that  improving  the  quality  of  WSS  services  and 
expanding  coverage  to  all  residents  is  essential  for  protecting  public  health,  raising  living 
standards, and achieving the Millennium Development Goals “to halve, by 2015, the proportion 
of the population without sustainable access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation”.1 These 
goals  are  ambitious,  especially  considering  the  current  state  of  the  physical  WSS  assets  that 
need urgent repair to avoid major system failures.  
 
In  the  early  years  after  independence,  the  Government  focused  mainly  on  rural  water 
2. 
supply  but,  in  the  past  decade,  it  also  has  turned  its  attention  to  improving  WSS  services  in 
urban areas, and this has now become a key focus. WSS systems in many smaller towns and 
district cities have reached the ends of their economic lives and require extensive rehabilitation. 
In  addition,  growing  urban  populations,  improving  living  standards,  and  demand  for  modern 
service levels require that existing systems be expanded. Providing high quality drinking water 
while  improving  living  standards  and  public  health  remain  key  challenges  to  the  Government. 
The  sector  faces  a  series  of  issues  in  need  of  urgent  attention:  (i)  rehabilitating  deteriorated 
infrastructure,  (ii)  improving  sector  development  strategies  and  planning,  (iii)  improving 
standards  and  specifications,  (iv)  modernizing  institutional  arrangements  and  capacity,  (v) 
strengthening water utilities (vodokanals)2 and providing additional financial resources, and (vi) 
updating water tariffs to match the costs related to the improved WSS service levels. 
 
3. 
Groundwater resources in Uzbekistan are becoming more polluted with salts, nutrients, 
and contaminants resulting from extensive use of agricultural chemicals in the collective farms 
over many decades. Many towns and cities are in water-scarce areas, with insufficient or poor-
quality groundwater or surface water sources. As a result, water for the towns and cities is often 
sourced from aquifers which, in many cases, are more than 70 kilometers distant. This adds to 
the  cost  of  water  supply.  For  towns  and  cities  where  local  groundwater  reserves  have  proven 
inadequate or unsuitable, a series of interregional trunk mains (IRTMs) and regional trunk mains 
have  been  constructed  to  supplement  the  existing  supplies.  There  are  six  IRTMs  and  three 
regional trunk mains in the country. These are the lifelines for supplying many industrial, urban, 
and rural areas and communities. The lack of local groundwater resources is now leading to a 
reexamination  of  surface  waters  and  groundwater  from  river  gravels  as  additional  sources  to 
meet the ever-expanding urban demand for good quality water.

G. 

Pricing Policy 

17. 
In 1996, the Government approved new normative acts toward gradual transition to self-
financing of the communal utilities sector (Resolution of the Government #271). The resolution 
defines  the  procedure  for  calculating  economic  tariffs  for  communal  services,  including  water 
supply  and  sanitation.  According  to  this  resolution,  tariffs  should  be  based  on  cost  of 
consumables  and  services,  plus  a  maximum  profit  margin  of  10%.  There  is  no  automatic 
upgrade  of  the  tariff  due  to  consumer  prices  inflation  and  increased  electricity  tariffs.  Instead, 
tariffs are currently reviewed every 6 months, but these are only increased at about 2%/annum. 
With very few exceptions, revenues of vodokanals are low. Many are incurring losses because 
of (i) high nonrevenue water (physical and administrative), (ii) inefficient pumps leading to high 
electricity  cost,  and  (iii)  the  deteriorated  state  of  the  systems  leading  to  numerous  repairs. 
Vodokanals  report  that  current  tariffs  are  below  recovery  for  even  operating  and  maintenance 
costs, and that there are no funds for 24-hour operation, replacement, or expansion. According 
to the MOF, however, the present tariff policy is set to force utilities to improve their efficiency.  
 
The  position  of  the  regulator  (Department  for  Financial  and  Price  Regulation  of  the 
18. 
Consumer Market and Services under the MOF) is that (i) significant improvements in financial 
viability  of  vodokanals  are  possible  if  local  government  administrations  and  vodokanal 
managements  would  exercise  the  political  will  to  introduce  modern  financial  management 
(including  to  update  and  computerize  consumer  databases)  and  better  tariff  collection  as  a 
precursor  to  rehabilitating  physical  infrastructure.  In  the  regulator’s  opinion,  the  Government 
needs assistance from donor agencies (e.g., bilateral aid agencies) in developing such financial 
management programs for selected utilities as a foundation for international financial institutions 
to make further capital investments into projects. Support of local state administrations is crucial 
for  prompt  tariff  collection  from  residential  and  nonresidential  consumers  and  for  sanctions 
against illegal or nonpaying connections. The Tashkent city administration is a good example of 
a successful vodokanal. It should be noted, however, that Tashkent, with its more than 1 million 
connections, has an advantage of scale economy not enjoyed by small vodokanals having only 
a few thousand connections. 
 
H. 

Sustainability of Investments 

19. 
To  improve  WSS  services,  the  Government  is  considering  ways  to  create  balance 
between  vodokanal  autonomy  and  municipal  regulation,  to  ensure  that  the  regulator  and 
regulated work together to obtain the best results for the beneficiaries. To date, this relationship 
has not been successful due to a lack of enforcement. Vodokanals need to be held responsible 
for managing and providing services as efficiently and prudently as possible. On the other hand, 
regulators must ensure that vodokanals have the freedom and incentives they need to manage 
their own affairs, and particularly to gradually establish tariffs at cost recovery levels.  
 
20. 
Institutional  strengthening  is  required  within  UCSA  to  implement  the  Government’s 
ambitious programs. Major intervention is needed to strengthen the IRTMs and vodokanals, to 
help them become autonomous, financially stable, and independent on a sustainable basis. The 
road map envisages a number of initiatives for (i) evaluating the possibility and advantages of 
aggregating  the  vodokanals  to  gain  economies  of  size,  (ii)  benchmarking  studies,  (iii) 
rationalizing  the  consumer  base  with  tax  rolls,  (iv)  rationalizing  staffing  requirements,  (v) 
increasing tariffs to meet full O&M costs, (vi) assisting the IRTMs in developing various options 
for  PPP,  (vii)  assisting  the  vodokanals  in  developing  options  for  performance-based  O&M 
contracts, and (viii) capacity building and training staff at all related organizations.

1. 
The economic analysis covers the four sample subprojects included in Tranche 1 of the 
Investment  Program.  It  was  undertaken  in  accordance  with  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
guidelines, including the guidelines and handbook for the economic analysis of projects and, in 
particular, those for the water supply sector.1 For the overall Investment Program, the analysis 
describes  the  economic  rationale  and  rationale  for  public  intervention.  The  analysis  assumes 
that in the “future without project” scenario the existing systems will continue to deteriorate and 
the level of services will further decline from 2009 levels. The economic analysis also evaluates 
the cost-effectiveness of individual sample subprojects, particularly for wastewater, focusing on 
least-cost  analysis  where  applicable.  The  subproject  analysis  compares  the  economic  internal 
rate  of  return  (EIRR)  with  the  economic  opportunity  cost  of  capital,  assumed  at  12%  for 
infrastructure  project  studies  in  Uzbekistan.  Sensitivity  and  risk  analyses  are  undertaken  to 
assess  the  robustness  of  the  subprojects  under  adverse  economic  conditions.  The  analysis 
uses shadow pricing and standard conversion factors to convert the financial cost and benefits 
into  economic  terms.  The  analysis  is  undertaken  in  constant  May  2009  prices.  Details  of  the 
economic analysis are presented in Supplementary Appendix N. 
 
B. 

Economic Rationale 

2. 
The  collapse  of  the  former  Soviet  Union  in  1991  brought  a  reduction  in  funding  and 
subsidies to the water supply and sanitation (WSS) sector in Uzbekistan. The country inherited 
a  comprehensive  WSS  systems  infrastructure  capable  of  servicing  the  majority  of  the 
population,  but  these  systems  are  now  reaching  the  end  of  their  useful  lives  and  require 
rehabilitation and modernization. The capital investment required to rehabilitate or upgrade the 
systems cannot be met solely by the national and local budgets, however, and as a result the 
water supply infrastructure in the country is faced with further deterioration.2  
 
3. 
To arrest the continued decline of water supply services, the Government has begun a 
number of key reforms,  including (i) improvements in water sector services through a national 
water  supply  development  plan;  (ii)  financial  sustainability  goals  through  cost  recovery;  (iii) 
adequate investment planning with domestic and external funding; (iv) further decentralization of 
WSS services; (v) introduction of private sector participation and public–private partnerships in 
the  sector;  (vi)  promotion  of  water  resources  conservation,  economic  use  of  water,  consistent 
water  quality  control,  and  sound  management  of  wastewater;  and  (vii)  improvements  in 
operational strategies through a stronger institutional setup and interagency collaboration in the 
sector, as well as capacity building. 
 
Government  intervention  derives  its  rationale  from  the  increasing  concern  over  the

however, that where such centralized systems exist, services continue to worsen because the 
vodokanals,  lacking  funds  and  capacity,  can  do  very  little  to  improve  and  rehabilitate  the 
systems  with  their  own  resources.  Low-quality  services  plus  significant  water  losses  in  the 
systems result in limited revenue generation. In many cases, revenues cannot even cover the

(iii)  sustainability  of  the  available  water  resource.  The  least-cost  solutions  were  found  most 
useful in evaluating wastewater treatment options for the design of the Termez wastewater and 
sewerage improvement subproject. Least-cost analysis was applied to three alternatives: a new 
lagoon treatment scheme, construction of a new wastewater treatment plant, and rehabilitation 
of the existing plant. The results showed rehabilitation of the existing wastewater treatment plant 
to be the most viable alternative. 
 
E. 

Economic Costs 

9. 
Costs were prepared based on constant prices applicable in May 2009. Economic costs 
exclude  taxes  and  duties.  Financial  prices  were  converted  to  economic  prices  using  standard 
conversion factors calculated from the cost breakdown. The shadow exchange rate factor was 
assumed to be 1.0. The shadow wage rate factor for unskilled labor was assumed to be 0.8. 
 
F. 

Socioeconomic Surveys 

10. 
Socioeconomic  surveys  cover  14%  of  total  households  in  Karmana  and  25.5%  in 
Galaasiya.  The  household  surveys  are  based  on  random  probability  samples,  which  ensure 
representation  equal  to  0.95.  The  limit  of  sampling  error  is  determined  by  the  target  level  of 
significance and does not exceed 5%. In the Karmana and Galaasiya  surveys, interviewing of 
households  was  face-to-face  while  using  a  questionnaire.  Focus  group  discussions  were 
conducted in Termez. 
 
11. 
To  identify  willingness  to  pay  (WTP),  closed-ended  questions  were  used  to  elicit 
household  preferences.  Tap  water  supply  24  hours  a  day  was  offered  as  the  service 
improvement. Households’ responses conform to economic theory as to there being a positive 
effect  of  income  on  WTP.  The  survey  showed  an  expressed  average  WTP  of  SUM936  per 
person  per  month  for  water  supply  in  Karmana  and  SUM1,068  in  Galaasiya.  WTP  figures  are 
also  consistent  with  findings  from  the  Surkhandarya  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation  Project, 
considering  local  inflation  and  the  fact  that  Bukhara  and  Navoi  provinces  are  considered  as 
more economically developed than Surkhandarya Province.5 
 
12. 
The surveys also indicate that existing water demands in Karmana and Galaasiya have 
been  constrained  by  the  limited  capacity  and  condition  of  the  piped  water  systems.  Current 
water  consumption  in  Karmana  and  Galaasiya  is  66  lpcd  and  72  lpcd,  respectively,  and 
80%−87% of the populations use water from pipelines in the house or yard and streets. Those 
remaining obtain water from water vendors, wells, and other sources.

the following projected local annual inflation rates: 10.6% in 2009, 9.5% in 2010, 8.5% in 2011, 
8% during 2012–2013, 7% in 2014, and 5% from 2015 onward.1

Financial  objectives.  The  proposed  tariff  rates  for  each  subproject  were  designed  to 
(i) fully recover operation and maintenance (O&M) costs, (ii) recover all subproject debt service, 
and  (iii)  generate  a  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR)  greater  than  the  weighted  average 
cost  of  capital  (WACC),  wherever  feasible.  In  addition,  each  subproject  was  projected  to 
maintain its accounts receivable at less than 60 days’ equivalent of annual sales by 2016. 
 
Operating  revenues. Operating revenues include water sales and repayment of water 
4. 
meters. Payment for a water meter was assumed to be made in 36 equal monthly installments

the loan to Uzbekistan Agency "Uzkommunhizmat" (UCSA) under a subsidiary loan agreement.

UCSA  will  manage  the  funds  allocated  for  Damkhoja  Inter-Regional  Trunk  Main  (IRTM)  and 
onlend the proceeds of the subsidiary loan for other subprojects to the corresponding provincial 
governments  on  the  same  terms.  The  provincial  governments  will  bear  the  foreign  exchange 
risks.
